items.title: Nobel peace prize officials investigate surge in bets for winner
items.standfirst: Bets for Maria Corina Machado spiked on Polymarket gambling site hours before she was awarded prizeNorwegian officials who oversee the Nobel peace prize are investigating suspicious online betting for this year’s winner that suggests a rare leak from the secretive committee that hands out the prize.Online bets for the Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado spiked on the Polymarket gambling site shortly after midnight on Thursday, Norwegian time, according to the information on its website. Continue reading...
items.content: Bets for Maria Corina Machado spiked on Polymarket gambling site hours before she was awarded prizeNorwegian officials who oversee the Nobel peace prize are investigating suspicious online betting for this year’s winner that suggests a rare leak from the secretive committee that hands out the prize.Online bets for the Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado spiked on the Polymarket gambling site shortly after midnight on Thursday, Norwegian time, according to the information on its website. items.title: Maria Corina Machado’s Nobel win: Insights from the Norwegian Nobel Committee
items.standfirst: Jorgen Watne Frydnes, Chair of the Norwegian Nobel Committee, joined FRANCE 24 shortly after announcing the Nobel Peace Prize winner, Maria Corina Machado. Frydnes discussed Machado’s tireless efforts as a leader of the democratic movement in Venezuela and explained the Committee’s selection process. This year’s choice highlights, according to him, a brave and courageous individual who embodies the core values of the prize.
items.content: Jorgen Watne Frydnes, Chair of the Norwegian Nobel Committee, joined FRANCE 24 shortly after announcing the Nobel Peace Prize winner, Maria Corina Machado. Frydnes discussed Machado’s tireless efforts as a leader of the democratic movement in Venezuela and explained the Committee’s selection process. This year’s choice highlights, according to him, a brave and courageous individual who embodies the core values of the prize.

items.title: Venezuelan politician María Corina Machado wins Nobel peace prize
items.standfirst: Opponent of Maduro regime receives award and praise for keeping ‘flame of democracy burning’The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado has won the Nobel peace prize for her dogged struggle to rescue the South American country from its fate as “a brutal, authoritarian state”.Machado, 58, a conservative often described as Venezuela’s Iron Lady, has spent the last year living in hiding after her political movement was widely believed to have beaten the country’s president, Nicolás Maduro, in the July 2024 presidential election. Continue reading...
items.content: Opponent of Maduro regime receives award and praise for keeping ‘flame of democracy burning’The Venezuelan opposition politician María Corina Machado has won the Nobel peace prize for her dogged struggle to rescue the South American country from its fate as “a brutal, authoritarian state”.Machado, 58, a conservative often described as Venezuela’s Iron Lady, has spent the last year living in hiding after her political movement was widely believed to have beaten the country’s president, Nicolás Maduro, in the July 2024 presidential election. Continue reading...

items.content: Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado, who lives in hiding, won the Nobel Peace Prize on October 10 for fighting dictatorship in her country.

items.title: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado wins Nobel Peace Prize
items.standfirst: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado was awarded the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize for fighting dictatorship and promoting democracy in the country. Machado, who lives in hiding, is the first Venezuelan national to win the Nobel Peace Prize.
items.content: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado was awarded the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize for fighting dictatorship and promoting democracy in the country. Machado, who lives in hiding, is the first Venezuelan national to win the Nobel Peace Prize.

items.title: Venezuela's opposition leader María Corina Machado wins 2025 Nobel Peace Prize

items.content: Venezuela's opposition leader María Corina Machado has won this year's Nobel Peace Prize for her tireless work promoting democratic rights for the people of Venezuela.(Image credit: Lexi Parra for NPR)

items.title: Nobel Peace Prize awarded to Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado

items.content: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded Friday to Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado, who lives in hiding after attempting to run for the presidency last year against President Nicolás Maduro

items.title: María Corina Machado of Venezuela awarded Nobel Peace Prize

items.content: People lift a banner and portraits of Israelis held hostage in the Gaza Strip during a rally in Tel Aviv on October 7, 2025. | Ahmad Gharabli/AFP via Getty Images After more than two years, Israel and Hamas have finally reached a ceasefire deal to free all remaining Israeli hostages and allow aid…

items.title: Gaza ceasefire: Who are the 20 living hostages set to be freed by Hamas before Monday night?
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have begun to implement a deal providing for a ceasefire and the release of the 20 Israeli hostages still believed to be alive in Gaza – and the return of the bodies of 26 captives presumed dead. Here's what we know about the hostages still held by Hamas.
items.content: Israel and Hamas have begun to implement a deal providing for a ceasefire and the release of the 20 Israeli hostages still believed to be alive in Gaza – and the return of the bodies of 26 captives presumed dead. Here's what we know about the hostages still held by Hamas.

items.title: Who are the 48 hostages still held in Gaza?
items.standfirst: A ceasefire deal should see Hamas hand over all 48 remaining Israeli and foreign hostages, 20 of whom are believed to be alive.
items.content: A ceasefire deal should see Hamas hand over all 48 remaining Israeli and foreign hostages, 20 of whom are believed to be alive.

items.title: All the hostages believed to be alive and who are due for release
items.standfirst: As Israel and Hamas finally strike a deal aimed at bringing an end to the war in Gaza, we take a look at the hostages still believed to be alive and who are set to return home any day now.
items.content: As Israel and Hamas finally strike a deal aimed at bringing an end to the war in Gaza, we take a look at the hostages still believed to be alive and who are set to return home any day now.

ai_summary: Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire to free hostages and allow aid.
The deal involves the release of 20 Israeli hostages believed to be alive.
48 hostages, including foreign nationals, are still held in Gaza.
The ceasefire is aimed at ending the war in Gaza.
The bodies of 26 deceased captives will also be returned.

items.title: Hamas will be disarmed, Netanyahu vows after ceasefire begins
items.standfirst: In combative speech, Israeli prime minister says Gaza will be demilitarised ‘the easy way or the hard way’Gaza ceasefire deal – live updatesBenjamin Netanyahu repeated his pledge to force Hamas to disarm in a defiant and combative speech on Friday just an hour after a ceasefire began in Gaza.In a televised address, Israel’s prime minister said he had resisted intense domestic and international pressure to achieve his aim of ensuring “the security of Israel”, and he lambasted his critics and reiterated a threat to return to war if necessary. Continue reading...
items.content: In combative speech, Israeli prime minister says Gaza will be demilitarised ‘the easy way or the hard way’Gaza ceasefire deal – live updatesBenjamin Netanyahu repeated his pledge to force Hamas to disarm in a defiant and combative speech on Friday just an hour after a ceasefire began in Gaza.In a televised address, Israel’s prime minister said he had resisted intense domestic and international pressure to achieve his aim of ensuring “the security of Israel”, and he lambasted his critics and reiterated a threat to return to war if necessary. items.title: Israeli military says ceasefire takes effect in Gaza, raising hopes for the hostages families
items.standfirst: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas came into effect in Gaza on Friday, following Cabinet approval of a deal to pause fighting and exchange the remaining hostages for Palestinian prisoners. The first hostage releases are expected soon. However, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has remained vague on whether this marks the end of the war, offering no clear commitment to a full cessation of hostilities as FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky explains.
items.content: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas came into effect in Gaza on Friday, following Cabinet approval of a deal to pause fighting and exchange the remaining hostages for Palestinian prisoners. The first hostage releases are expected soon. However, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has remained vague on whether this marks the end of the war, offering no clear commitment to a full cessation of hostilities as FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky explains.

ai_summary: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas is now in effect.
Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu vowed Hamas will be disarmed.
The first hostage releases are expected soon.
Netanyahu threatened to return to war if necessary.
The Israeli military confirmed the ceasefire's implementation.

items.title: Trump officials cancel major solar project in latest hit to renewable energy
items.standfirst: Esmeralda 7 in Nevada would have produced enough energy to power 2m homesThe Trump administration has killed a huge proposed solar power project in Nevada that would have been one of the largest in the world, indicating that the White House plans to attack not only wind power but all renewable energy.On Thursday, the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) changed the status of the Esmeralda 7 project to say its environmental review has been “cancelled”, the climate publication Heatmap first reported. Continue reading...

clusters.title: France: New PM expected soon, left parties voice disappointment
clusters.neutral_headline: French Political Crisis: New Prime Minister Expected Soon

items.title: France: New PM expected soon, left parties voice disappointment
items.standfirst: The meeting between President Macron and France’s main political parties ended Friday with no clear breakthrough. Left-wing parties expressed disappointment over the process and lack of progress. A new prime minister is expected to be appointed within the next few hours. FRANCE 24's journalists Ellen Gainsford and Rochelle Ferguson have the analysis.
items.content: The meeting between President Macron and France’s main political parties ended Friday with no clear breakthrough. Left-wing parties expressed disappointment over the process and lack of progress. A new prime minister is expected to be appointed within the next few hours. FRANCE 24's journalists Ellen Gainsford and Rochelle Ferguson have the analysis.

items.title: Could a technocratic government end France’s political crisis?
items.standfirst: France’s political crisis deepens after Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s resignation, with President Macron meeting parties at the Élysée Palace to avoid snap elections and find a new prime minister. The left appears more united than the divided right, fueling talks of a technocratic government as a possible way out, as FRANCE 24's Rochelle Ferguson analyses.
items.content: France’s political crisis deepens after Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s resignation, with President Macron meeting parties at the Élysée Palace to avoid snap elections and find a new prime minister. The left appears more united than the divided right, fueling talks of a technocratic government as a possible way out, as FRANCE 24's Rochelle Ferguson analyses.

items.title: Last-ditch talks underway to appoint French Prime minister and resolve crisis
items.standfirst: Following Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s resignation, President Emmanuel Macron has brought together political parties at the Élysée Palace in a final effort to avoid snap elections and find a new prime minister. As our journalist Ellen Gainsford reports, the left wing appears more united than the right amid ongoing talks to resolve France’s political crisis.
items.content: Following Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s resignation, President Emmanuel Macron has brought together political parties at the Élysée Palace in a final effort to avoid snap elections and find a new prime minister. As our journalist Ellen Gainsford reports, the left wing appears more united than the right amid ongoing talks to resolve France’s political crisis.

items.title: Macron summons parties for crunch meeting in frantic effort to appoint PM
items.standfirst: All parties except National Rally and La France Insoumise called on by president to show ‘collective responsibility’Europe live – latest updatesEmmanuel Macron has summoned the leaders of several political parties to his office to demand they show “collective responsibility” as he attempts to appoint a new prime minister amid a deepening political crisis.All political parties except Marine Le Pen’s far-right National Rally, which is the biggest single opposition party, and Jean-Luc Mélenchon’s leftwing La France Insoumise were called to the meeting at the presidential palace before Macron’s self-imposed deadline to name a new prime minister by Friday night. Continue reading...
items.content: All parties except National Rally and La France Insoumise called on by president to show ‘collective responsibility’Europe live – latest updatesEmmanuel Macron has summoned the leaders of several political parties to his office to demand they show “collective responsibility” as he attempts to appoint a new prime minister amid a deepening political crisis.All political parties except Marine Le Pen’s far-right National Rally, which is the biggest single opposition party, and Jean-Luc Mélenchon’s leftwing La France Insoumise were called to the meeting at the presidential palace before Macron’s self-imposed deadline to name a new prime minister by Friday night. Continue reading...

items.title: France’s political crisis: All efforts to avoid snap elections
items.standfirst: President Emmanuel Macron is meeting with all major political parties—except the far-right RN and the far-left LFI—in an effort to resolve France’s deepening political crisis and agree on a new prime minister. Following Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s resignation and failure to form a government, parties are aiming to avoid snap elections and ensure the national budget is passed before year’s end, as Antonia Kerrigan reports.
items.content: President Emmanuel Macron is meeting with all major political parties—except the far-right RN and the far-left LFI—in an effort to resolve France’s deepening political crisis and agree on a new prime minister. Following Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s resignation and failure to form a government, parties are aiming to avoid snap elections and ensure the national budget is passed before year’s end, as Antonia Kerrigan reports.

ai_summary: President Macron met with French political parties, but no breakthrough was achieved.
Left-wing parties expressed disappointment over the lack of progress in the meetings.
A new prime minister is expected to be appointed within the next few hours.
President Macron is trying to avoid snap elections and find a new prime minister.
All parties except National Rally and La France Insoumise were called to the meeting.

clusters.title: Seven people killed after twin earthquakes off coast of Philippines
clusters.neutral_headline: Earthquakes Off Philippines Coast Trigger Tsunami Warnings

items.title: Seven people killed after twin earthquakes off coast of Philippines
items.standfirst: Quakes of 7.4 and 6.8 magnitude trigger tsunami alerts as people living near coast advised to evacuateTwo powerful offshore earthquakes struck off the coast of the southern Philippines on Friday, killing at least seven people, while towns near the epicentre faced structural damage and authorities warned of strong aftershocks.The first quake of magnitude 7.4, in waters off the town of Manay in the province of Davao Oriental, triggered a tsunami alert for coasts within 186 miles (300km) of the epicentre, but the warnings for the Philippines and Indonesia were subsequently lifted. Continue reading...
items.content: Quakes of 7.4 and 6.8 magnitude trigger tsunami alerts as people living near coast advised to evacuateTwo powerful offshore earthquakes struck off the coast of the southern Philippines on Friday, killing at least seven people, while towns near the epicentre faced structural damage and authorities warned of strong aftershocks.The first quake of magnitude 7.4, in waters off the town of Manay in the province of Davao Oriental, triggered a tsunami alert for coasts within 186 miles (300km) of the epicentre, but the warnings for the Philippines and Indonesia were subsequently lifted. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Two earthquakes struck off the coast of the southern Philippines, killing at least seven.
The first quake had a magnitude of 7.4, triggering tsunami alerts.
Tsunami warnings were issued for several countries after the earthquake.

Warnings for the Philippines and Indonesia were subsequently lifted.

clusters.title: Discord says hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users
clusters.neutral_headline: Discord Says Hackers Stole IDs of 70,000 Users

items.title: Discord says hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users
items.standfirst: As more sites require IDs for user age verification, expect more such breaches to come.
items.content: Discord says that hackers made off with images of 70,000 users’ government IDs that they were required to provide in order to use the site. Like an increasing number of sites, Discord requires certain users to provide a photo or scan of their driver's license or other government ID that shows they meet the minimum age requirements in their country. In some cases, Discord allows users to prove their age by providing a selfie that shows their faces (it’s not clear how a face proves someone’s age, but there you go). The social media site imposes these requirements on users who are reported by other users to be under the minimum age for the country they’re connecting from. “A substantial risk for identity theft” On Wednesday, Discord said that ID images of roughly 70,000 users “may have had government-ID photos exposed” in a recent breach of a third-party service Discord entrusted to manage the data. The affected users had communicated with Discord’s Customer Support or Trust & Safety teams and subsequently submitted the IDs in reviews of age-related appeals.Read full article Comments

items.title: ID photos of 70,000 users may have been leaked, Discord says
items.standfirst: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.
items.content: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.
